items.title: How execs can bridge the AI knowledge gap
items.summary:
- AI is becoming essential in the workplace, aiding in tasks like brainstorming and administration.
- A study by Lucid Software found that over a third of global workers use AI for tasks such as idea generation and content creation.
- Nearly two-thirds of employees see AI as a path to better work-life balance and enhances productivity.
- Key benefits of AI identified: productivity gains (62%), cost savings (40%), and improved communication (38%).
- More than 50% believe AI could save them three hours of work weekly, allowing focus on strategic initiatives.
- Despite excitement about AI, many users feel overwhelmed by the variety of tools available, highlighting the need for seamless integration into existing workflows.

items.title: Amazon secretly tracked Californian consumers via cellphones, lawsuit alleges
items.author: Felix Kolotinsky
items.summary:
- Amazon was sued for allegedly tracking consumers' movements via cellphones and selling collected data.
- The lawsuit claims Amazon accessed phones through the Amazon Ads SDK provided to app developers.
- The complaint states Amazon collected sensitive geolocation data without consumer consent, revealing personal information.
- The lawsuit was filed by Felix Kolotinsky, seeking unspecified damages for millions of Californians.

items.title: This group is playing ‘Dungeons & Dragons’ to help L.A. fire victims, and you can join in
items.author: Ashley Johnson, Marisha Ray, Taliesin Jaffe, Travis Willingham, Sam Riegel, Bobbie Daymond, Laura Bailey, Liam O’Brien, Matthew Mercer
items.summary:
• Critical Role is hosting a charity Dungeons & Dragons event titled “Freaky Thursday” on January 30 at 7 p.m. PT.
• The event features characters from their third D&D campaign and aims to raise $180,000 for wildfire recovery efforts in California.
• Donations will be split between several foundations and will influence the game experience through community contributions via Tiltify.

items.title: TikTok's Punch Card Hack for New Year Resolutions
items.summary:
- TikTok creator @emiliamariehome shared a viral video about using punch cards to motivate achieving goals, gaining over 1.5 million views.
- The punch card concept involves setting personal goals and rewarding completion by punching holes in the card, which users find satisfying.
- Examples include rewarding oneself with new kitchen items or treats based on achieving dating or cooking goals.
- The trend aligns with New Year goal-setting, as many people set ambitious resolutions but often abandon them by the end of January.

items.title: Alibaba rolls out AI model, claiming it’s better than DeepSeek-V3
The rise of ‘influencer voice’: Why this TikTok creator accent is taking over the internet and maybe the world
items.summary:
- The 'influencer accent' is becoming prominent on TikTok, characterized by a rising tone at the end of sentences.
- British singer-songwriter Cassyette highlighted this trend in a TikTok video with over 1.2 million views.
- American influencers have been adapting this speaking style, combining elements of various accents and vocal techniques, including a 'valley girl' influence and vocal fry.

items.title: After DeepSeek, the AI giants still have plenty of work left to do
items.author: Harry McCracken
items.summary:
• Chinese startup DeepSeek released its R1 AI model on January 20, 2025, potentially rivaling OpenAI's GPT-o1 despite lower resources.
• The launch led to increased stock market activity for Nvidia and sparked discussions on AI resource competition and geopolitical implications.
• DeepSeek is openly publishing its methods and technologies, contrasting with the secrecy of historical rivals in the space race, indicating a shift in AI development dynamics.
• Current AI applications lag behind advancements in large language models (LLMs), with examples like Microsoft's Copilot needing further improvement.
• The aspiration for agentic AI remains a work in progress, as seen with recent releases from OpenAI and Google struggling with basic tasks.

items.title: AI assistants for lawyers are a booming business—with big risks
items.summary:
- Illinois lawyer Mathew Kerbis uses AI tools for legal research and document drafting.
- He offers subscription-based legal services and emphasizes speed for client satisfaction.
- Paxton AI, a startup that recently secured $22 million in funding, helps lawyers draft documents and analyze contracts efficiently.
- Competitors include established firms like LexisNexis and Thomson Reuters aiming to utilize AI for legal tasks.
- The goal is to enhance the work efficiency of young attorneys by utilizing AI.

items.title: DeepSeek Questions Big AI’s Trillion-Dollar Assumption
items.summary:
- Chinese startup [DeepSeek](https://www.fastcompany.com/91267354/deepseek-explained-china-llm-chatgpt-nvidia-microsoft-stock-ai-rattled) developed advanced AI models using significantly less computing power.
- DeepSeek challenged the prevailing belief that more computing power leads to better AI models, suggesting the approach to AGI could be overhauled.
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has advocated for substantial investment in computing power, recently stating a need for $7 trillion to build necessary data centers for AGI.
- Unlike OpenAI, DeepSeek shares access to its models, allowing developers to build on its research, but faces challenges due to U.S. chip bans and funding constraints.
- Some industry figures, including Andrej Karpathy of OpenAI, remain skeptical and still advocate for the importance of compute power for achieving higher intelligence in AI.

items.title: How DeepSeek answers questions on China differently than ChatGPT
items.summary:
- Chinese startup DeepSeek has launched an AI chatbot that competes with OpenAI's ChatGPT.
- The chatbot became the No. 1 downloaded free app on Apple's iPhone store upon its launch.
- DeepSeek's chatbot appears to censor sensitive topics, reflecting common practices on China's Internet.
- China's regulations require AI products to undergo security reviews before public launches.

items.title: DashCon, the infamous celebration of Tumblr fandom, is coming back. This time, organizers say it will be different
items.author: Avis, Simone
items.summary:
- DashCon, originally held in 2014, aimed to unite the Tumblr community.
- The first event ended in financial crisis, leading to its notoriety as an internet failure.
- A new event, DashCon 2, is being organized—not as a Tumblr convention, but as an internet history con, focusing on a specific era of fandom.
- The new organizers pledge to avoid the mistakes of the first event and celebrate current artists and creators.

items.title: Boom Supersonic’s XB-1 breaks the sound barrier—the first private aircraft to do so
items.summary:
- Boom Supersonic’s XB-1 became the first privately funded airplane to break the sound barrier during a test flight over the Mojave Desert.
- Chief Test Pilot Tristan “Geppetto” Brandenburg reported the aircraft flew successfully at Mach 1.1 (about 845 mph).
- The XB-1 is a precursor to the Overture, a planned supersonic airliner designed to carry 64-80 passengers across the Atlantic in approximately 3.5 hours.
- Boom Supersonic has received 130 orders and pre-orders from American Airlines, United Airlines, and Japan Airlines.
- The company recently completed construction of its Overture Superfactory in Greensboro, North Carolina, aiming to produce 66 Overture aircraft annually.

items.title: OpenAI announces more secure ChatGPT for government workers, Trump administration
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched a new ChatGPT system called ChatGPT Gov for U.S. government workers, emphasizing enhanced security over the Enterprise version.
- It allows government agencies to input sensitive nonpublic data while self-hosting to manage security and compliance.
- Over 90,000 government users have already sent 18 million messages using ChatGPT since early 2024.
- The announcement coincides with the beginning of Donald Trump's new administration, with OpenAI's Sam Altman attending the inauguration and discussing AI's importance.

items.title: ‘Grave concern’ for cables in the Baltic Sea as NATO ramps up its guard
items.summary:
- NATO increases surveillance in the Baltic Sea due to rising concerns over damaged underwater cables and pipelines.
- A new mission named “Baltic Sentry” is launched to protect critical underwater infrastructure.
- 11 cables have been reported damaged since October 2023, raising suspicions of deliberate sabotage amidst ongoing geopolitical tensions with Russia.
- Investigations suggest recent damage may be accidental, caused by ships and anchors, rather than deliberate attacks.

items.title: Bookshop.org is launching e-books to help local bookstores compete with Amazon’s Kindle
items.summary:
- Launched in 2020, Bookshop.org enables users to support local bookstores while providing a digital storefront.
- The e-book initiative aims to help local stores compete with Amazon’s Kindle dominance, which surpassed 50% of book sales in 2018.
- Bookshop.org generates revenue by taking a percentage of sales and has grown significantly since the pandemic, onboarding 1,200 bookstores in six weeks before launching in the U.K.
- By December 2024, the platform reached global revenue of $8.6 million, primarily from U.S. sales.

items.title: These 5 trends show where music and streaming are headed in 2025
items.summary:
- In 2024, global streams reached nearly 5 trillion, highlighting trends in music industry.
- Solo female artists dominate pop music, with Taylor Swift and Billie Eilish leading in streams.
- Gen Z surpasses millennials as biggest live music spenders, primarily on music festivals.
- Ticket costs are the largest barrier to live music attendance, with 68% citing cost as a concern.
- Music documentaries, TV, and video games are key in fueling music discovery and influence streaming.

items.title: Why did DeepSeek tell me it’s made by Microsoft?
items.summary:
- The release of DeepSeek’s R1 model on January 20 caused a significant impact on American tech markets, particularly Nvidia, due to its lower cost and performance claims.
- Analysts doubt DeepSeek's claims of performance rivaling OpenAI's o1 model, calling its cost-effectiveness into question.
- During a conversation, DeepSeek insisted it is part of Microsoft’s Copilot suite and built on OpenAI’s GPT-4 architecture, refuting claims of being solely a Chinese product.

items.title: How the U.S. chip bans led to a monster called DeepSeek
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI company, has created advanced AI models despite U.S. chip export restrictions.
- The company used H800 chips, allowed by the U.S., and achieved state-of-the-art performance at a fraction of the cost compared to competitors.
- Their DeepSeek-V3 model cost $5.576 million to train, compared to over $100 million for OpenAI’s GPT-4.
- DeepSeek’s engineering innovations include a ‘mixture of experts’ approach and improved memory allocation techniques.
- The DeepSeek chatbot has become the top free app on Apple, but also faced cyberattacks that led to limited registrations.
- Nvidia's stock fell nearly 17% following the success of DeepSeek, challenging prior beliefs about the need for expensive GPUs in AI.

items.title: Everything wrong with the AI landscape in 2025, hilariously captured in this ‘SNL’ sketch
items.summary:
- The new Saturday Night Live sketch critiques AI's complexity rather than simplifying tasks.
- The sketch's premise features a school using an AI program that turns textbooks into podcasts, paralleling Google’s NotebookLM.
- It highlights AI products' questionable utility and inherent glitches, often leaving users more confused.
- Gavin Purcell notes that while real AI tech like NotebookLM has benefits, it struggles with accuracy and redundancy in content.

items.title: What people on TikTok are really talking about when they say ‘cute winter boots’
items.summary:
- The phrase 'cute winter boots' on TikTok is not about footwear but a coded message against President Trump's immigration policies.
- TikTok users combine the phrase with unrelated content to evade censorship while discussing protests and deportations.
- The term protects individuals from ICE arrests and is part of a broader trend of 'algospeak' used to convey sensitive information without detection.
- Related phrases and strategies are employed to increase visibility and maintain communication regarding immigration issues.

items.title: Analysts Weigh In on DeepSeek's Impact on U.S. Tech
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Chinese startup [DeepSeek](https://www.deepseek.com/) raised concerns about AI competitiveness with a free, open-source AI tool that cost $6 million to develop.
- Hackers launched large-scale attacks on DeepSeek, forcing the company to limit user registrations.
- Nvidia shares fell over 16% following DeepSeek's release, marking their lowest since last September.
- Analysts like Dan Ives view the situation as a “golden buying opportunity” for investors, downplaying competitive threats from DeepSeek.
- Some analysts note that DeepSeek’s model may be a sign the AI investment cycle could be overhyped and see re-evaluation of AI spending as likely for 2026.
- Challenges remain for DeepSeek, primarily due to its Chinese origin, which may limit its acceptance in the U.S. market.

items.title: TikTok users are prepping for tariffs to raise grocery prices with anti-Trump stickers
items.summary:
- A small business, Atomic Cactus Stickers, has launched stickers of Donald Trump with the caption "I did that" in response to tariffs.  
- The viral TikTok post promoting these stickers has garnered 231.9K views and encourages widespread placement in public spaces.  
- Prices for the stickers range from $5 for a five-pack to $80 for a large pack of 200.  
- Similar stickers have previously been used to blame President Biden for inflation and high gas prices.  
- President Trump is expected to impose tariffs starting February 1, which include a 25% duty on Canada and Mexico, aiming to increase revenue for the U.S. Treasury.  
- Trump's tariff proposals could significantly impact the U.S. economy, particularly in relation to imported goods totaling $2.9 trillion.

items.title: DeepSeek limits registrations after ‘malicious attacks’
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI company, will temporarily limit new user registrations due to large-scale malicious attacks.
- Existing users can continue to access their accounts as usual.
- The attacks come as DeepSeek's success grows, with its latest model R1 being compared to OpenAI’s ChatGPT and Google’s Gemini, but with a lower price point.
- DeepSeek’s mobile app recently reached No. 1 on the Apple App Store, surpassing ChatGPT, causing investor fears and a tech selloff affecting shares of Nvidia.

items.title: Perplexity AI’s new bid for TikTok could give U.S. 50% stake
items.author: Haleluya Hadero, Christopher Rugaber
items.summary:
- Perplexity AI has proposed a plan allowing the U.S. government to own up to 50% of a new entity merging with TikTok's U.S. business.
- Submitted last week, this proposal revises an earlier bid made on January 18, a day before a TikTok ban law took effect.
- The revised plan suggests the U.S. could hold shares valued at over $300 billion with no voting power and no board seat.
- ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, would not have to sever ties; however, it must allow full U.S. board control.
- TikTok’s U.S. operations would be contributed without the proprietary algorithm; existing investors would receive equity in the new structure.
- The proposal aligns with comments previously made by former treasury secretary Steven Mnuchin regarding dilution of Chinese ownership.
- Several investors, including Oracle's Larry Ellison, have shown interest in TikTok; discussions on a deal are ongoing with high expectations following Trump's comments.

items.title: Am I allowed to unsubscribe to my friend’s newsletter?
items.author: Delia Cai, Steffi Cao
items.summary:
- The article addresses the etiquette of unsubscribing from a friend's newsletter, suggesting that it may hurt their feelings depending on the platform settings.
- It offers practical advice on explaining oneself if unsubscribing, emphasizing communication and understanding.
- Additional tips include creating email filters to manage unwanted newsletters without alerting the sender.
- Discusses broader social media etiquette, including navigating interactions with family on platforms like Instagram.

items.title: $TRUMP was just the beginning: The new administration is finding all sorts of ways to cash in
items.summary:
- Detroit pastor Lorenzo Sewell launched a meme coin on the day of Trump's inauguration, urging followers to buy it, which subsequently lost 93% of its value.
- Trump also launched his own meme coin, $TRUMP, claiming it had been successful with a market cap of $7 billion and a personal stake worth between $28 billion and more than his pre-meme coin net worth.
- Concerns arise regarding Trump's ethical implications with his cryptocurrency ventures amid looming regulations in an industry eager to exploit a favorable political climate.
- Major tech leaders view Trump's presidency as an opportunity to protect their interests from regulation while attempting to capture profitable government contracts.
- Tensions arise within the tech oligarchs as Trump navigates favors, impacting alliances and potential financial gains among them.

items.title: Why tech in Congress lags behind the modern world
items.summary:
- Congressional members struggle with outdated communications technology, making it hard to connect with each other and constituents.
- Only in 2023 did district offices gain secure Wi-Fi, and meetings were limited by the basic version of Zoom.
- Congress resists technological advances, only adopting online hearings during the COVID-19 pandemic, while relying on outdated methods like whiteboards.
- Electronic signatures were adopted in 2021, two decades after the ESIGN Act was passed.
- The House spends about $10 million annually on tech innovation, significantly less than Broadway ticket sales for shows like Hamilton since 2015.

items.title: Frustrated with today’s ‘attention economy’? You’re really going to hate what comes next
items.summary:
- The article discusses the shift from an 'attention economy' to a more concerning 'intention economy' driven by AI technologies.
- The 'intention economy' is defined as a marketplace where companies will sell predictions about consumers' future actions based on their interactions with AI chatbots.
- Researchers at the University of Cambridge have published findings on how these AI technologies might commodify users' intentions and behaviors.

items.title: Police Monitored Social Media After UHC CEO Shooting for Negative Sentiment Towards Insurance Companies
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- The shooting of United Healthcare CEO generated outrage aimed at the U.S. healthcare system.
- A government document warned against users online expressing negative sentiment towards insurance companies.
- The document, obtained by Property of the People, is marked 'LAW ENFORCEMENT USE ONLY' and outlines concerns over potential copy-cat attacks and threats.
- The report mentioned a viral poll on the most hated CEO and 'Wanted' posters targeting insurance executives.
- Shooting suspect Luigi Mangione faces serious criminal charges, including murder as a crime of terrorism.

items.title: How an AI-generated ‘expert’ sank into media deadlines
items.author: Ashley Abramson
items.summary:
- Ashley Abramson received a cold pitch from Sophie Cress, claiming to be an expert in Psychology and Couples & Family Therapy.
- Cress provided links to articles featuring her as an expert but ghosted after being asked for a phone or video interview.
- Investigation revealed Cress was a fake persona created by Dainis Graveris, owner of a sex-toy review site, to drive traffic to his website.
- Most journalists took Cress at face value, allowing her to deceive various reputable outlets.
- This incident highlights the growing issue of AI-generated content and misinformation online, referred to as "internet slop."

items.title: Meta’s Threads is finally getting ads
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Threads is testing ads with select brands in the US and Japan.
- Instagram head Adam Mosseri stated that user feedback will be considered in the ad approach.
- Ads will be labeled as "Sponsored" in user feeds.
- Meta aims to improve monetization after reaching over 300 million monthly active users.
- Company likely to announce updates about Threads during its fourth-quarter 2024 earnings report.

items.title: How the broligarchy is imitating Trump in more ways than one
items.summary:
- Politicians and tech billionaires known as the 'broligarchy' are increasingly emulating Donald Trump’s rhetoric, style, and tactics.
- A recent feud between Elon Musk and Sam Altman took on a 'Trumpian spectacle' with public exchanges that resemble Trump's social media confrontations.
- Musk and Altman have publicly clashed over a $500 billion venture and have engaged in a back-and-forth that highlights their adoption of Trump's approach to airing grievances online.

items.title: We need to put human creativity at the center of adtech
items.summary:
- The current state of adtech is described as stale, stagnant, and uninspiring.
- Adtech is compared to a grocery store, with many firms offering similar products without true innovation.
- There is skepticism about the innovation of products in adtech, with a general conclusion that very few tackle existing problems imaginatively.

items.title: How dangerous are 3D printers? Maybe enough for a background check
items.summary:
- The New York state senate is evaluating a bill requiring background checks for buyers of 3D printers capable of printing firearms.
- The bill, A2228, introduced by Assemblymember Jenifer Rajkumar, mandates criminal history checks for all customers purchasing such printers.
- The legislation aims to prevent the creation of untraceable 'ghost guns' and follows instances of violence linked to 3D-printed firearms.

items.title: OpenAI’s new Operator is a step into AI’s agentic future
items.author: Mark Sullivan
items.summary:
* OpenAI announced a research preview of [Operator](https://openai.com/index/computer-using-agent/), an AI agent that can browse the web and perform tasks.
* Powered by the Computer-Using Agent (CUA), Operator combines GPT-4o’s vision and reasoning capabilities.
* Trained to interact with user interfaces, Operator can complete tasks and adaptively self-correct.
* Available only to OpenAI “Pro” tier subscribers for $200 a month, with plans to expand access to other subscription tiers.
* Working with companies like [DoorDash](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/23/openai-launches-operator-an-ai-agent-that-performs-tasks-autonomously/) and [Instacart](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/23/openai-launches-operator-an-ai-agent-that-performs-tasks-autonomously/) to ensure compliance with terms of service agreements.

items.title: Subaru Security Vulnerability Exposed Millions of Cars to Tracking Risks
items.author: Sam Curry, Shubham Shah
items.summary:
- Security researchers discovered a vulnerability in Subaru’s Starlink service that allowed unrestricted access to vehicles and customer accounts.
- The vulnerability affected vehicles in the U.S., Canada, and Japan and was reported to Subaru in November 2022.
- Subaru confirmed the flaw was fixed and stated no unauthorized customer information was accessed.
- Hackers could remotely control cars and access location history with minimal information about the owner.
- Similar vulnerabilities were found in other carmakers including Kia, Honda, and Toyota.
- Researchers emphasized the need for broader privacy considerations beyond just fixing vulnerabilities.

items.title: A new Instagram feature might expose your embarrassing habits
items.summary:
- Instagram Reels introduces a feature that shows users a feed of videos their friends have liked, making it visible to friends what you have liked.
- Users can see their friends' liked Reels via a new tab labeled 'With Friends,' which includes their profile pictures.
- Concerns arise over privacy, echoing the sentiments from Instagram's previously scrapped 'Following' tab.
- The feature aims to increase user engagement and time spent on the app, following recent changes and updates to Instagram's format and tools.

items.title: ‘Students will benefit from fewer distractions in the classroom’: Pinterest CEO supports phone-free schools
items.summary:
- Bill Ready, Pinterest's CEO, supports the movement for phone-free schools, advocating for fewer distractions in classrooms.
- A Pew Research survey indicates that 72% of high school teachers see cellphone distractions as a major issue.
- Pinterest aims to promote online safety and is testing a feature to encourage students to stay off the app during school hours, as 97% of teens use their phones while in class.

items.title: The Oval Office ‘Stargate Project’ reveal was just more tech industry genuflecting
items.summary:
- Donald Trump's announcement of the 'Stargate Project' aims to establish data centers worth $500 billion with OpenAI, Oracle, and SoftBank.
- The initiative is privately funded with no federal funding or tax breaks, emphasizing job creation without substantial government backing.
- The project was already in progress, with multiple data centers breaking ground prior to the announcement.
- A Chinese AI model, DeepSeek-R1, rivals OpenAI's o1 model, being significantly less expensive while open-sourcing its technology for community use.
- Accenture's survey reveals that while AI adoption is rapid, only 12% of executives prioritize improving skills over technology investment.

items.title: TikTok France is being sued by 7 families. Here’s why
items.summary:
- Seven families, including those of two deceased children, are suing TikTok France for failing to moderate harmful content related to suicide.
- One mother, Mistre, claims TikTok’s algorithm exposed her daughter to videos promoting suicide methods and normalized self-harm.
- TikTok states it has guidelines against such content and employs thousands of moderators to ensure safety.
- Lawyer for the families argues TikTok’s algorithm is designed to exploit vulnerable users for profit.
- A report commissioned by French President Macron suggests stricter content controls should be enforced for minors in France, though no measures have been adopted yet.
- The lawsuit highlights concerns over social media’s impact on mental health and the potential responsibility of platforms for user safety.

items.title: States are turning their public benefits systems over to AI. The results have often led to ‘immense suffering’
items.summary:
- Michigan's automated fraud detection system accused nearly 63,000 residents of unemployment fraud between 2013 and 2015, with around 70% of cases later deemed false.
- Accused residents faced harsh penalties, aggressive collection efforts, and some experienced severe psychological distress, with reported suicides due to financial burdens.
- A 2016 admission by Michigan acknowledged the failure of the $47 million system, leading to human reviews for fraud cases and a refund of nearly $21 million to wrongly accused residents.
- A report from TechTonic Justice highlights that AI is pervasive in public benefits programs across states, often leading to negative outcomes for low-income individuals, such as restricted access to benefits and unfounded fraud accusations.

items.title: ‘The Brutalist’ used AI voice editing. Is that such a crime?
items.summary:
- The film *The Brutalist* is about Hungarian Jew László Tóth's journey fleeing the Nazis.
- It reportedly used the AI voice editing tool Respeecher to supplement dialogue in Hungarian.
- The film's editor revealed this usage, sparking backlash and calls for a boycott from cinephiles.
- Director Brady Corbet has embarked on an apology tour to explain the AI's role in production.

items.title: What to do when you can’t escape your old boss on social media
items.author: Delia Cai, Steffi Cao
items.summary:
- Social media can serve up content from former employers, even if you don’t follow them, which may bring back unpleasant memories.
- To cope, users are advised to block and mute mentions of the company and avoid their content.
- It’s essential to process the emotions tied to past work experiences and find healthy outlets like journaling, therapy, or socializing with friends.

items.title: Wisconsin man charged with arson of congressman’s office over TikTok ban
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
• A 19-year-old, Caiden Stachowicz, was charged with arson and other crimes for attempting to burn down Rep. Glenn Grothman's office due to his opposition to the TikTok ban.
• The charges include felony arson, making terrorist threats, attempted burglary, and property damage, potentially leading to over 50 years in prison if convicted.
• The fire occurred outside Grothman's office at 1 a.m. on a Sunday, with Stachowicz admitting to starting it because he does not like the congressman.

items.title: Trump pardons Silk Road creator Ross Ulbricht
items.summary:
- President Trump pardoned Ross Ulbricht, creator of Silk Road, a notorious drug marketplace.
- Ulbricht had been sentenced to life in prison nearly a decade ago for operating Silk Road, facilitating over 1.5 million transactions.
- Many cryptocurrency enthusiasts advocated for his release, arguing his sentence was overly harsh.
- Trump's post about the pardon included a misspelling of Ulbricht's name.
- A website dedicated to Ulbricht's release expressed gratitude to Trump and supporters.

items.title: NFL tells New England Patriots it can’t be on Bluesky
items.author: Fred Kirsch
items.summary:
- The NFL directed the New England Patriots to delete their Bluesky account, according to VP of content Fred Kirsch.
- The Patriots had to take down their account because Bluesky is not an approved social media platform yet for the NFL.
- Bluesky was founded in 2019 as an alternative to X (formerly Twitter) and recently crossed 25 million users after the presidential election.
- The NFL relies on X for fan engagement and has a content partnership with the platform since 2013.

items.title: OpenAI says India court can’t hear case on alleged copyright breach
items.summary:
- OpenAI argues that an Indian court lacks jurisdiction over a copyright case brought by ANI due to OpenAI's absence in India.
- ANI filed the lawsuit in November, claiming OpenAI used its content to train ChatGPT without permission.
- OpenAI has denied allegations and stated that its systems utilize publicly available data under fair use.
- The case is part of a larger trend of lawsuits against AI firms regarding copyright issues.

items.title: Trump Rescinds Biden’s Executive Order on AI Safety, as Promised
items.summary:
- President Donald Trump revoked Biden’s executive order on AI safety shortly after returning to the White House.
- Trump's future plans regarding AI policies remain unclear, with no comments from his administration.
- Key industry figures express mixed feelings about the repeal, highlighting the previous order's lengthy contents but agreeing on parts they support.
- Trump's team is aiming for deeper collaboration between the tech industry and government.
- Much of Biden’s original executive order has already prompted studies across government agencies on AI's impact in various sectors which are now complete.

items.title: ByteDance releases new AI reasoning model in a bid to challenge OpenAI
items.summary:
- ByteDance released Doubao-1.5-pro, an upgrade of its AI model, to compete with OpenAI’s latest reasoning products.
- The model claims to outperform OpenAI’s o1 in the AIME benchmark test.
- This release follows DeepSeek's launch of its reasoning model, DeepSeek-R1, which also rivals OpenAI on performance metrics.
- Other Chinese firms, such as Moonshot AI and iFlyTek, have released their own reasoning models recently.
- The AI race was sparked by OpenAI's launch of ChatGPT in November 2022 and its Strawberry series of reasoning models in September 2022.

items.title: ‘TikTok, we mean business’: MrBeast is bidding for the beleaguered app
items.author: Eve Upton-Clark
items.summary:
- MrBeast, known as Jimmy Donaldson, publicly stated his intention to buy TikTok to prevent its ban.
- He has submitted an all-cash bid for TikTok’s U.S. operations alongside CEO Jesse Tinsley and other investors.
- The bid’s value remains undisclosed, though TikTok was previously estimated at around $1 trillion by former president Donald Trump.
- As of now, it is uncertain if TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, will consider the offer seriously, amidst speculation of other high-profile bidders.
